title: Korean I
requirements: Not for students who have taken KORE2000,2001,2050(1010),3000,3001,3002,3050 or 3051
description: This course invites students without prior knowledge of Korean to explore the basic features of the Korean language. Supported by audiovisual aids, students will receive intensive practice in spoken and written Korean through interactive class work, homework and online exercises. They will become familiar with the basic concepts of Korean grammar and learn how to interact in some simple everyday situations.
outcome: At the end of the course, students will be able to speak, read and write simple Han Geul (Korean writing system) having familiarity with current Korean society and its culture. They will be able to speak about topics such as everyday greetings, asking and giving information, shopping.

title: Korean III
requirements: 1.Not for students who have taken KORE3000,3001,3002,3050(2010) or 3051(3010);2.Prerequisite: KORE2000 (1002) or 2050 (1010)
description: This course aims to further enhance students’ communication skills in the four language domains listening, speaking, reading and writing. Students are expected to communicate confidently in a wider range of social interactions including more formal situations and simple professional contexts as well as reporting past events and sharing experience. At the end of this course, students will have completed a proficiency level comparable to level 1 of the Test of Proficiency in Korean (TOPIK).
outcome: Upon successful completion of the course, students should be able to  (1)improve their basic communication skills with expanded vocabulary, expressions and grammar. (2)know how to address strangers or staff with questions and requests using the polite formal verb endings. (3)be more accustomed to Korean traditional and modern culture and social life.

title: Korean IV
requirements: 1.Not for students who have taken KORE3001,3002,3050(2010) or 3051(3010);2.Prerequisite: KORE2001
description: This course aims at increasing students’ communicative fluency in oral and written Korean. Using a variety of classroom activities and multimedia, students will build up their competence in the four language domains listening, speaking, reading and writing. Through intensive practice they will be able to communicate in a wide range of social situations with the appropriate awareness of the pragmatic rules involved. title: Korean V
requirements: 1.Not for students who have taken KORE3002 or 3051 (3010) ;2.Pre-requisite: KORE3000 (2002) or 3050 (2010)
description: This course focuses on the further development of communication skills in Korean with emphasis on the expression of personal views and the training of argumentative strategies. The course will also engage students in critical reflections on various aspects of life in Korean and their own social environment. Students will be guided to analyze various types of data to support their views. They will learn how to express their wishes and aspirations using the appropriate registers.
outcome: Upon successful completion of the course, students should be able to  (1) improve their communication skills with argumentative strategies; (2) obtain a better listening skill by learning various types of spoken expressions used in modern Korean society; (3) increase comprehensive understanding in written text without knowing every word inside of it;  (4) be more accustomed to traditional and modern culture in Korean.

title: Korean VI
requirements: Not for students who have taken KORE3051 (3010). ;Prerequisite: KORE3001.
description: This course builds on the knowledge acquired through previous Korean language courses. It aims at leading students to a proficiency level comparable to the threshold from level 2 to level 3 of the Test of Proficiency in Korean (TOPIK). To achieve this goal, students will be encouraged to work project-based through independent or collaborative work with their peers. At the end of this course students will have mastered the most important grammar features of Korean and be able to communicate effectively in a wide range of everyday situations and a number of professional contexts. They will be able to use their oral and written language skills to relate to, reflect on and analyze past and current issues involving the Korean society.
outcome: Upon the completion of this course, students should demonstrate the ability to  use the four language skills listening, speaking, reading and writing with confidence in a wide range of situational contexts;  collect information independently and present in class using the appropriate language registers;  discuss, compare and evaluate issues related to Korean society and international affairs.

title: Sounds of Korean
requirements:
Prerequisites: KORE3000,3001,3002,3050 or 3051
Not for students who have taken KORE3100 in 2nd term 2018-19 and 1st term 2019-20
description: This course introduces the phonetic system of the Korean language. Supported by audiovisual aids, students will understand the sound of the vowels and consonants, the pronunciation rules and the intonations in different contexts of the Korean language. The articulation of some Korean sounds that are more difficult for Chinese speakers will also be examined. Through interactive classroom learning activities, students’ accuracy of Korean pronunciation will be enhanced.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able to: (1) produce the sound of each vowel and consonant accurately; (2) identify phonetic rules and apply them to pronunciation properly; (3) reduce pronunciation errors; (4) produce rhythmically correct sentences; (5) identify meaning-change through intonation; (6) speak accurately and fluently; (7) ultimately increase self-confidence in speaking.
syllabus: Topic Content   Vowels and Consonants Vowels(1) Single-vowels: ㅏ, ㅓ, ㅗ, ㅜ, ㅡ, ㅣ, ㅔ, ㅐ(2) Double-vowels: ㅘ, ㅝ, ㅟ, ㅚ, ㅞ, ㅙ / ㅑ, ㅕ, ㅛ, ㅠ, ㅖ, ㅒ, ㅢ   Consonants(1) Sounds of basic consonants: ㅁ, ㅂ, ㄴ, ㄷ, ㄹ, ㅅ, ㅈ, ㄱ, ㅇ, ㅎ(2) Aspiration: ㅋ, ㅌ, ㅍ, ㅊ(3) Glottal tension: ㄲ, ㄸ, ㅃ, ㅆ, ㅉ   Syllable-final consonants(1) Single-final consonants: [ㄱ], [ㄴ], [ㄷ], [ㄹ], [ㅁ], [ㅂ], [ㅇ](2) Double-final consonants   Pronunciation Rules Linking: 한국어[한구거], 앉아요[안자요], 좋아요[조아요] etc.Glottalization: 학교[학꾜], 앉다[안따], 할 수[쑤] 있다, 여권[여꿘], etc. Nasalization: 박물관[방물관], 음료수[음뇨수], etc. Aspiration: 어떻게[어떠케], etc.Lateralization: 설날[설랄], etc.Insertion of ‘ㄴ’: 무슨 일[무슨닐], etc.    Intonation (1) Intonation of statements (2) Intonation of questions(3) Intonation of propositive sentences(4) Intonation of imperative sentences(5) Intonation of exclamational sentences

title: Korean Conversation
description: This course provides students with opportunity to develop their oral proficiency in Korean. Supported by teacher’s guidance and audiovisual materials, students will practice spoken Korean intensively in diverse sociocultural settings through interactive class work and homework. Preassigned readings before the class enhance students’ reading skills and understanding the background of each discussion session. They will practice speaking in a variety of speech styles, from the most casual dialogues to formal group discussions. Students will explore how to develop communication skills more appropriately in various social contexts in this process.
outcome: Upon successful completion of the course, students should be able to  (1) understand the different methods of communication that suits each different social context and improve their overall speaking proficiency  (2) use the most culture-appropriate Korean vocabulary and expressions. (3) explore communication strategies to become better communicators
syllabus: Topic Contents       Communication through one-to-one conversation in different social contexts    Learning Korean etiquettes in different social settings Practicing different Korean verb endings according to the social contexts (e.g. at home/school /work, etc.) and different relationship with the interlocutors (e.g. close friends /parents /colleagues at work, etc.) Learning a variety of lexical items used in spoken language, such as commonly used idioms, abbreviations, slangs, dialects and so on        Thinking about communication strategies on how to compensate one's linguistic knowledge breakdown Role-playing with learned contents to improve speaking skills          Communication throughDiscussions    Reading a variety of stories and articles posted on Blackboard. Students are expected to complete the readings prior to the class in which they are discussed. Learning how to express one's own opinions  (topics: differences between Korean traditional and contemporary culture)  Learning how to discuss efficiently Learning how to support and oppose one's opinions.         Communication through Presentation    Learning useful expressions used in presentation Learning how to improve presentation skills Learning how to cope with insufficient linguistic knowledge

title: Creative Writing in Korean
requirements:
Prerequisites: KORE3001,3002 or 3051
Not for students who have taken KORE3100 in 2nd term 2019-20
description: This course aims to improve students’ creative writing skills in Korean. It includes a systematic review on the grammar of Korean language and various activities for students to practice their writing skills. In each writing task, students will recognize their personal writing style and reduce common mistakes by receiving peer evaluation and the teacher’s feedback. Also, students will create a portfolio to keep track of their writing progress. This course encourages students to build confidence in writing, explore different writing skills, and produce texts align with them.
outcome: Upon successful completion of the course, students should be able to  (1) comprehend, identify, interpret, analyse and evaluate ideas from diverse texts. (2) write coherent texts using lexico-grammatical choices appropriate to the task (3) improve writing skills by analyzing frequent and common mistakes (4) evaluate critically their own and the other’s written materials

title: Business Korean
description: This course introduces learners of Korean to useful vocabulary and essential communicative skills in a Korean-speaking business environment. The topics are organized in language functions such as writing business emails, giving business presentations, and conducting and attending job interviews. Sufficient opportunities to enhance the four basic language skills (listening, speaking, reading and writing) in the business setting will be provided. Students will be exposed to a wide range of authentic materials taken from the traditional media and the internet, and participate in a variety of learning activities such as group discussions, role-play tasks and oral presentations. This course highlights cultural factors in the practice of business in Korea and aims to improve corresponding cross-cultural communicative skills therein.
outcome: By the end of the course, students will be able to:  1. Improve their Korean language abilities in a business context.  2. Understand simple oral and written business messages in Korean.  3. Carry out basic oral and written business conversations in Korean.  4. Respond to a direct exchange of information on familiar and routine business matters in Korean.  5. Demonstrate an increased awareness of the cultural traits of the Korean-speaking society and the differences in intercultural business communications.

title: Korean through Drama
description: This course aims to improve students’ communication skills through Korean multi-media such as TV dramas, movies and songs. It emphasizes the training of listening and speaking skills in authentic everyday situations as they are presented in Korean media, particularly in popular TV dramas. Since the multi-media materials not only provide authentic communication situations but also present real life cultural elements, students will be able to gain a better understanding of many aspects of Korean society while practicing their four language skills. Producing a drama in the middle and the end of the term will be a major assessment method to help students develop their creativity and fluency.

title: Special Topics in Korean
description: This course aims at furthering students' understanding of selected area(s) of Korean language, literature or culture. Topics will vary from year to year. Offerings with different subtitles can be taken up for credit, up to a maximum of two times.
outcome: At the end of this course, students demonstrate the ability to: - undertake projects that integrate the insights of language and culture studies. - discuss and analyse language phenomena, literary productions or cultural representations of Korean. - make use of their linguistic, literary or cultural knowledge to critically assess and evaluate productions and representations in Korean language, literature and culture.
